description:
The four central themes of nursing (person, environment, health and nursing) will form the basis for an exploration of the health and illness related issues facing young and middle aged adults. A functional status conceptual framework encompassing a biopsychosocial approach to nursing practice will be used. The course will present a comprehensive overview of functional status impairments, developmental concerns, assessment parameters, common health problems, treatment modalities, nutritional interventions, nursing care strategies, resources and barriers to treatment, psychosocial needs as well as ethical and cultural considerations. Clinical application of content covered will occur in an acute care hospital setting. 

Students will care for young and middle aged adults recovering from illness and injury and participate in one observational experience which may include the operating room/post-anesthesia care unit, pain experience team, hemodialysis, transplant team, HIV outpatient experience or ostomy experience.
name: NURSING CARE OF YOUNG & MIDDLE AGED ADULT: THEORY/CLINICAL

section.name: NURSING CARE OF YOUNG & MIDDLE AGED ADULT: THEORY/CLINICAL

values.comments:
The four central themes of nursing (person, environment, health and nursing) will form the basis for an exploration of the health and illness related issues facing young and middle aged adults. A functional status conceptual framework encompassing a biopsychosocial approach to nursing practice will be used. The course will present a comprehensive overview of functional status impairments, developmental concerns, assessment parameters, common health problems, treatment modalities, nutritional interventions, nursing care strategies, resources and barriers to treatment, psychosocial needs as well as ethical and cultural considerations. Clinical application of content covered will occur in an acute care hospital setting. Students will care for young and middle aged adults recovering from illness and injury and participate in one observational experience which may include the operating room/post-anesthesia care unit, pain experience team, hemodialysis, transplant team, HIV outpatient experience or ostomy experience.

Students reported that the class had good content but there was not enough time to cover all of the material. Many found the class to be extremely helpful in learning the pathophysiology and nursing management of the adult client. There was a general consensus that a good amount of time was needed to complete out-of-class preparation for the clinical experience. As a result, students suggested that the distribution of grades should reflect this time dedication. Overall, the students felt it was a “great class” and “challenging.”

Professor Walsh-Brennan was described by students as “clearly very knowledgeable” about the content. There were a few students who felt Professor Walsh-Brennan did “not speak loudly enough” even after requests to speak up. Students enjoyed Professor Walsh-Brennan’s “excellent content” and availability to students.

Students felt the exams in this class did not always reflect the course material presented in lecture. There were highly detailed questions that were confusing. The additional work necessary for clinical made the readings and assignments in class more difficult to get done on time. This class is a requirement for junior nursing students either in the fall or spring semester. The prerequisites include N104, N106, N131, N132. The class has a clinical component which makes it inappropriate for non-nursing students to take.

section.name: NURSING CARE OF YOUNG & MIDDLE AGED ADULT: THEORY/CLINICAL

values.comments:
The four central themes of nursing (person, environment, health and nursing) will form the basis for an exploration of the health and illness related issues facing young and middle aged adults. A functional status conceptual framework encompassing a biopsychosocial approach to nursing practice will be used. The course will present a comprehensive overview of functional status impairments, developmental concerns, assessment parameters, common health problems, treatment modalities, nutritional interventions, nursing care strategies, resources and barriers to treatment, psychosocial needs as well as ethical and cultural considerations. Clinical application of content covered will occur in an acute care hospital setting. Students will care for young and middle aged adults recovering from illness and injury and participate in one observational experience which may include the operating room/post-anesthesia care unit, pain experience team, hemodialysis, transplant team, HIV outpatient experience or ostomy experience.

Students reported that the class had good content but there was not enough time to cover all of the material. Many found the class to be extremely helpful in learning the pathophysiology and nursing management of the adult client. There was a general consensus that a good amount of time was needed to complete out-of-class preparation for the clinical experience. As a result, students suggested that the distribution of grades should reflect this time dedication. Overall, the students felt it was a “great class” and “challenging.”

Professor Klenke-Borgman was described as an “excellent resource for the students.” The lectures by Professor Klenke-Borgman were nicely done and organized. Students said that Professor Klenke-Borgman had “gone out of her way” often to ensure students understood the content. Most stated that Professor Klenke-Borgman was readily available and accessible if there were problems in the course.

Students felt the exams in this class did not always reflect the course material presented in lecture. There were highly detailed questions that were confusing. The additional work necessary for clinical made the readings and assignments in class more difficult to get done on time. This class is a requirement for junior nursing students either in the fall or spring semester. The prerequisites include N104, N106, N131, N132. The class has a clinical component which makes it inappropriate for non-nursing students to take.
